Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: Several other volunteers can easily cover the first part of the shift if someone shows up a little late.
Story: I glanced at the clock as I finished my breakfast, my mind already on the volunteer shift I was scheduled for in half an hour. I knew I should leave soon to be on time, but as I passed the living room, I saw my mom sitting quietly, her hands folded in her lap, eyes distant. Dad was unusually silent too, staring at his coffee. I remembered how important it was to check in with them, to make sure everything was okay at home. They’d always told me how much it meant when I asked, “Is everything going well?” But if I started that conversation now, I’d definitely be late for my shift. I knew the other volunteers could cover for me for a bit, but I also felt guilty for not being as reliable as I should be. My heart tugged in two directions—toward my parents, who might need me, and toward my commitment to the volunteer team, who counted on me to show up. I stood in the hallway, keys in hand, torn between the two worlds that both expected so much from me.
